structure_content.summary: Presents a catalog of other books by Dr. Muata Abhaya Ashby, including 'Egyptian Yoga' volumes, 'The African Origins of Civilization', 'The Mysteries of Isis', 'Egyptian Proverbs', 'The Path of Divine Love', 'Maat Philosophy', 'Meditation', 'The Glorious Light Meditation', 'The Serpent Power', 'The King of Egypt', 'From Egypt to Greece', 'The Forty Two Precepts of Maat', 'The Egyptian Book of the Dead Mysticism', 'Anunian Theology', and 'Healing the Criminal Heart', all part of the Egyptian Yoga Series, covering diverse aspects of Kemetic mysticism.

structure_content.chapter_title: MUSIC BASED ON THE PRT M HRU AND OTHER KEMETIC TEXTS
structure_content.summary: Lists music CDs by Sehu Maa (Muata Ashby) based on 'Prt M Hru' and other Kemetic texts, including 'Adorations to the Goddess', 'Adorations to Ra and Hetheru', 'Merit's Inspiration', 'Songs to Asar Aset and Heru', 'Haari Om: Ancient Egypt Meets India in Music', 'Ra Akhu: The Glorious Light', and 'Glories of the Divine Mother'. These are instrumental and vocal chants designed for meditation and devotional practice.

key_concepts.definition: An Ancient Egyptian word and symbol meaning 'union', defined as 'the way or wisdom of the hidden Divinity which is behind all Creation'. It is also the proper name for Ancient Egyptian Religion, referring to 'the hidden way of the Divine Self' (i.e. God).

An Ancient Egyptian word and symbol meaning 'union'. 'Smai Tawi' means 'union of the two lands' (Upper and Lower Egypt), referring to the union of the Higher Self (Heru) and lower self (Set), and control of one's breath (Life Force). It is the Ancient Egyptian equivalent of 'Egyptian Yoga'.

Ancient Egyptian 'words of power' or 'utterances' that impart spiritual teachings and affirm spiritual truths. These are recited with meaning and feeling to transform consciousness, acting as mystic formulas for self-alchemy.

A philosophy, spiritual symbol, and cosmic energy representing Order, Righteousness, Justice, Balance, Harmony, and Truth. It is the divinity that manages Creation, the fulcrum of Karma, and the spiritual path for cultivating virtuous qualities in the human heart.

An Ancient Egyptian divinity, also known as Osiris. He is referred to as the 'Lord of the Perfect Black', symbolizing the essence of all things and the Higher Self (soul) within every human being, which struggles to regain its original state of perfection. Asar is an Avatar, a divine incarnation into time and space.

An Ancient Egyptian divinity, also known as Horus. He is the incarnation of Asar, representing the dynamic manifestation of the Spirit. Heru symbolizes the spiritual rebirth, aspiration for freedom, and triumph of the Higher Self over the lower self (Set), leading to spiritual enlightenment.

An Ancient Egyptian divinity representing the unbridled lower self, egoism, and evil forces. He symbolizes impulsiveness, reckless passions, greed, hatred, and the destructive tendencies that hinder spiritual progress.

An Ancient Egyptian divinity, also known as Thoth or Hermes. He is the god of right reason, wisdom, and knowledge, serving as the master teacher who initiates aspirants on the spiritual path of wisdom and assists in bringing justice.

An Ancient Egyptian divinity, also known as Anubis. He is the son of Asar and Nebethet, symbolizing discriminative knowledge and the guide to the initiate, leading souls to the abode of the Supreme Being. He represents the dawn when darkness turns to light and is the 'Opener of the Ways'.

An Ancient Egyptian goddess of creation and war, also known as Neith. She represents honor, decisive action, and is an androgynous primordial Supreme Divinity with a female aspect, seen as the source of light and the weaver of the physical universe.

The immortal spirit or ethereal being of a human, referred to as the 'being of light' or 'luminous being'. The Khu illumines the personality and is an aspect that becomes dim when one indulges in worldly consciousness.

The soul or 'Higher Self', symbolized by the Jabiru bird. It is an indestructible, eternal spark of life that dwells in the Ka, possessing the power of metamorphosis and existing apart from the body. The Ba is a spark from the Universal Ba (God).

The 'glorious' spiritual body in which the Khu and Ba dwell. It represents the deified natural body, where spiritual and mental attributes are united. The Sahu is the goal of all aspiration, allowing for God-like existence while alive.

The shadow or outline of the soul, a subtle image of self (ego) that is illumined by the light of the Spirit. It is a subtle manifestation of personality elements that consume spiritual energy and produce the individual personality.

The heart or seat of the mind, representing the deep unconscious mind, conscience, and repository of unconscious impressions gathered from past experiences. It is the source of Meskhenet (Karma) and the mother of reincarnation.

The Life Force or Power that exists in the universe and in humans. It is the vital Life Force used in fashioning one's glorious new body for resurrection, and the dynamic aspect of a person’s personality in the Astral Plane.
The 'name' of a being, an essential attribute to personification. It is associated with the 'mouth' and 'water', and is protected by a cartouche (rope of sunlight/Life Force harnessed into a circle).

The concrete personality or physical body, composed of solid aspects (bones, skin, blood, sense organs). The Khat is transient and mortal, one of the grosser aspects of the personality that dies with the physical body.

An Ancient Egyptian word and hieroglyphic symbol meaning 'rest', 'peace', and 'satisfaction'. In mystical terms, it denotes supreme peace, the final abode of those who achieve union with their Higher Self, and transcendental peace beyond thoughts and duality.

A term with several important implications: 'vindicated', 'righteous of speech', 'spiritually victorious', 'purity of heart', and 'strong of will in speech'. It is the highest spiritual attainment, knowing truth from untruth, and the Self from the not-self, achieved through righteous living and physical, mental, and moral purity.

The Serpent Power or Kundalini energy, which is latent within every human being's spiritual body. Its cultivation through Maat teachings leads to the awakening of spiritual consciousness and opens up the various psycho-spiritual energy centers.

The Netherworld or Astral Plane, a subtle plane of existence where souls experience conditions (heaven or hell) based on their karma. It is the realm of the subconscious and unconscious human mind, and a reflection of Cosmic Consciousness.

The 'Beautiful West' or 'hidden region' in the Duat, also known as the Netherworld and the abode of Asar. It is the final destination for enlightened souls who have understood their oneness with Asar, becoming a place of supreme peace and immortality.

A mythical solar bird, the prototype of the Greek Phoenix, symbolizing resurrection through fire. It represents Ra (the sun that dies at night to be reborn in the morning) and is a higher form of existence attained by the enlightened soul.

An Indian Sanskrit term meaning 'deed or action', equivalent to Ancient Egyptian 'Ari' or 'Iri'. It refers to one's actions and the certain experiences and consequences that follow, influencing one's destiny and reincarnation cycles.

An Ancient Egyptian term for reincarnation, meaning 'repeated embodiment' or 'coming back of the soul'. It is the continuous cycle of birth-death and rebirth into a new body until the soul is purified and returns to its divine source.

Seven psycho-spiritual energy centers located in the subtle body along the spine, depicted as spheres or chain links in Egyptian symbolism (Uraeus) and Lotuses (padmas) in Indian Yoga. Mastering these centers is crucial for spiritual evolution.

A symbol of Asar’s backbone, representing a 'firmly established, straight column' and the upper energy centers (chakras). Raising the Djed Pillar symbolizes raising consciousness and the resurrection of Asar, leading to spiritual strength and the awakening of the human soul.

practical_system.description: The core operative system is 'Egyptian Yoga' or 'Shetaut Neter', aiming for 'spiritual enlightenment' and 'union with the Divine Self'. It's a three-stage process: 1. Listening to wisdom teachings on reality and the Self. 2. Reflecting on and incorporating these teachings into daily life. 3. Meditating on their meaning to achieve transcendental consciousness. The system involves purifying the mind and body, controlling senses and desires, and transforming ego-consciousness into cosmic awareness. The ultimate goal is 'Maakheru' (spiritual victory/truth-speaking) and 'Nehast' (resurrection/spiritual awakening), recognizing one's true identity as the Absolute.
tools: Spiritual scriptures (Prt M Hru, Egyptian Yoga series, Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, Christian Bible, Gnostic Gospels).
Altar (a designated clean space for spiritual practice).
Candle (symbolizing singular consciousness and divine light).
Incense (invoking divine awareness and promoting positive vibrations).
Ankh symbol (representing eternal life and union of opposites).
Sculpture or picture of a Deity (e.g., Heru, Aset) for devotional focus.
Audio cassette recorder and recordings (chants, divine music, guided meditations).
Headrest (symbolic tool for meditation on death and spiritual awakening).
Heart-scarab amulet (placed within the heart area for opening the mouth ceremony).
Ritual instruments (adze of Upuaut, iron harpoon) for symbolic opening of mouth/eyes.
Rosary or 'mala' (beads for keeping track of mantra repetitions).
rituals: Listening to wisdom teachings on the nature of reality and the Self.
Reflecting on and incorporating wisdom teachings into daily life.
Meditating on the meaning of the teachings (Subtle One-pointed Mentation).
Formal Meditation Practice: Cleansing and purification (bath), wearing reserved clothing, selecting a quiet space, lighting candles and incense, assuming proper posture (Lotus or corpse-mummy pose).

Hekau/Mantra Recitation: Repeating words of power (e.g., 'Om', 'Amun-Ra-Ptah', 'I am That I am') audibly, humming, or silently, with meaning and feeling, to change mental states and direct consciousness.
Selfless Service (Karma Yoga): Performing actions for the benefit of others and the Divine, without expectation of reward, to purify the heart and sublimate the ego.

Cultivation of Virtues (Maat Principles): Living according to Maat's 42 precepts (e.g., truth, non-violence, self-control, righteous action/speech/worship, balance of mind, not-stealing, sex-sublimation).
Discipline of Detachment and Dispassion: Releasing attachment to worldly objects, desires, and emotions, viewing them as transient and illusory.
Opening the Mouth Ceremony: Symbolically expanding consciousness and memory of the true Self, releasing mental fetters.
Raising the Djed Pillar: Activating and raising the psycho-spiritual energy centers (Serpent Power/Kundalini) along the spine to elevate consciousness.
Eucharist Ritual: Symbolically consuming the 'Eye of Heru' (divine action/essence of God) through offerings (bread, wine) to assimilate divine nature and achieve god-consciousness.
Adorations and Invocations: Propitiating the Divine, either generally or to specific Neteru, as a form of devotional expression and prayer.
Controlling the Senses: Practicing Pratyahara (withdrawal of senses) through understanding and willpower to achieve inner peace and clear insight.

relevant_quotes.text: The Egyptians neither entrusted their mysteries to everyone, nor degraded the secrets of divine matters by disclosing them to the profane, reserving them for the heir apparent of the throne, and for such of priests as excelled in virtue and wisdom.”
“Never forget, the words are not the reality, only reality is reality; picture symbols are the idea, words are confusion.”
Self knowledge is the basis of true knowledge.
Soul to heaven, body to earth.
Man is to become God-like through a life of virtue and the cultivation of the spirit through scientific knowledge, practice and bodily discipline.
Salvation is accomplished by the efforts of the individual. There is no mediator between man and {his/her} salvation.
The visible world is ephemeral, the spirit world is forever; gain strength from this since nothing physical can destroy you.

Labor not after riches first, and think thou afterwards wilt enjoy them. He who neglects the present moment, throws away all that he hath. As the arrow passes through the heart, while the warrior knew not that it was coming; so shall his life be taken away before he knoweth that he hath it.
There is no happiness for the soul in the external worlds since these are perishable, true happiness lies in that which is eternal, within us.
Be chief of the mysteries at festivals, know your mouth, come in Hetep (peace), enjoy life on earth but do not become attached to it; it is transitory.
The wise person who acts with Maat is free of falsehood and disorder.

Neither let prosperity put out the eyes of circumspection, nor abundance cut off the hands of frugality; they that too much indulge in the superfluities of life, shall live to lament the want of its necessaries.

See that prosperity elate not thine heart above measure; neither adversity depress thine mind unto the depths, because fortune beareth hard against you. Their smiles are not stable, therefore build not thy confidence upon them; their frowns endure not forever, therefore let hope teach you patience.
An action is repaid by its like, and to every action there is a consequence.
Adversity is the seed of well doing; it is the nurse of heroism and boldness; who that hath enough, will endanger himself to have more? Who that is at ease, will set their life on the hazard?
There is no life for the soul except in knowing, and no salvation but doing.

The choice of the earthly condition is made by the soul itself, and very generally it differs from what it has been in the preceding term of life in this world. The cause is in him who makes the choice and the divinity is without blame in the matter.
Get thyself ready and make the thought in you a stranger to the world-illusion.
The whole period of things done on the earth is but a period of a dream.

Truth is but one; thy doubts are of thine own raising. It that made virtues what they are, planted also in thee a knowledge of their pre-eminence. Act as Soul dictates to thee, and the end shall be always right.
I am that I am.
The senses give the meaning from a worldly point of view; see with the spirit and the true meaning will be revealed. This is the relationship between the object and its Creator, its true meaning.
Knowledge derived from the senses is illusory; true knowledge can only come from the understanding of the union of opposites.
To free the spirit, control the senses; the reward will be a clear insight.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism as it presents Ancient Egyptian mystical philosophy ('Shetaut Neter') as a foundational system for spiritual evolution. It draws direct parallels to Hermeticism, Gnosticism, and various Yoga traditions, arguing that these later systems derived from or correlate with Egyptian originals. The text re-contextualizes the 'Book of the Dead' as an operative magical manual for spiritual transformation, moving beyond purely academic or literal interpretations. Its emphasis on self-knowledge, control of the lower self, and union with the Divine Self aligns with core esoteric aims, while its detailed treatment of Neteru (divinities) as cosmic forces and psychological principles provides a technical framework for magical understanding.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes serious spiritual aspirants, practitioners of Yoga and mystical traditions, academic researchers in comparative religions and esotericism, and individuals interested in Ancient Egyptian philosophy for personal transformation and enlightenment. It is explicitly not for those seeking superficial knowledge, entertainment, or dogma, but for those committed to deep study, reflection, and practice under spiritual guidance.
